title: Spain’s Sánchez calls for country to reunite after Catalan verdicts
text:
Acting Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez | Oscar Del Pozo/AFP via Getty Images Spain’s Sánchez calls for country to reunite after Catalan verdicts No one is punished for their ideas in Spain, acting PM says.

Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez called for unity in the wake of a court decision to sentence Catalan separatist leaders for carrying out a failed independence bid in 2017.

“After the sentencing, coexistence,” Sánchez told journalists after a two-day summit of EU leaders in Brussels. He then repeated the sentence for emphasis.

The secessionists, nine of whom will serve jail terms of up to 13 years, were convicted for sedition, disobedience and misuse of public funds.

Days of violent demonstrations have rocked Barcelona since the court's decision, leading to at least 130 injuries and flight cancellations at the city's airport.

Sánchez warned: “There will be no space for impunity regarding the vandalism we have seen in the last few days in some Catalan cities.” And he paid homage to the police, saying “they are acting in a model way.”

“The legalization of the political crisis has now ended after the sentencing of the Supreme Court. I believe that we cannot repeat a path that has filled Catalan society with frustration, failure and fracture. Now we need to open a new chapter.”

Sánchez, an acting PM who faces a second general election in November, defended the Supreme Court’s ruling. “In Spain all freedoms, all rights and all opinions are respected and no one is punished for his or her ideas, only for actions when these contravene legal democracy.”

On Monday, Catalonia's President Quim Torra, who has called for a fresh independence vote, said the sentences were “an act of vengeance, not an act of justice.” He also condemned the violence on Catalan streets.

In Brussels, Sánchez called on the independence movement to recognize that “Catalonia is not one single people … it’s a diverse society, a plural society, and so you can’t homogenize something that is pluralistic and diverse.”

The Spanish Supreme Court also issued a new EU arrest warrant for former Catalan leader Carlos Puigdemont, who voluntarily appeared before Belgian authorities on Friday.
description: No one is punished for their ideas in Spain, acting PM says.
